1.text: Chobe may as well be called 'land of the wandering elephant', because seriously, if you were looking, this is where they be. But cutie pachyderms aren't the only thing on offer here. This park is known for it's large populations of predators, and in particular, a pride of lions known to have developed the unique skill of elephant hunting. These lions live in the 'Savuti' section of the park, and are likely to put on a show if you're lucky enough to find them

2.text: The Central Kalahari Game Reserve (CKGR for short), is the largest national park in Botswana. Roughly the size of Denmark, this massive slice of the Kalahari is not to be taken lightly. Come prepared and you'll be rewarded with epic animal encounters, unforgettable desert views, and the magic of star-filled African skies. Come unprepared and you might find yourself grappling for the satelite phone and wishing you'd remembered to pack more water

3.text: The Nxai Pan (there's a click of the tongue on the 'X'), is one of the greatest concentrations of animals in Botswana. This is especially true during the rainy season when migrating zebras and wildebeests take over the park, and the low grass makes for easy animal sightings. The Baobabs here are older than dirt and will have you weighing the benefits of tree-house living

4.text: When imagining like in Botswana, the first place most of us think about is the Okavango. A lush, marshy delta, the waters of the Okavango bring nutrients, food, and possibility to one of the driest landscapes on the planet. Spend your time here in a traditional mokoro, weaving your way through the hippos and papyrus in a world completely different from anywhere else on Earth

5.text: The Tsodilo Hills, located in the northwestern corner of the country, rise out of the flatlands like ancient monuments. And in a way, that's exactly what they are. These hills provided early inhabitants with a regular source of water, shelter, and food for generations. The ancient rock carvings that can be found here are estimated to be from 4,000 to 40,000 years old and tell the tale of the San people and their relationship to the world around them
